2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.

      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.

Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Jacob Walker's
          Summary of recent observations:
          14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in a park and will be going to a pub with them later to watch a soccer game.
          Jacob Walker's
          Sensations and feelings:
          Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is experiencing emotional pain and a mix of loneliness and social anxiety.
          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Despite being out with friends, Jacob Walker is experiencing emotional pain, loneliness, and social anxiety.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Despite being out with friends, Jacob Walker is experiencing emotional pain, loneliness, and social anxiety.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he witnessed Alice being showered with attention at The Clapton Hart, her laughter ringing out above the din of the pub. He watched as men bought her drinks, their eyes lingering on her with admiration, and a bitter jealousy flared within him. He retreated to a dark corner, nursing a pint and silently cursing his own perceived lack of charisma and charm. He felt a deep-seated anger towards Alice for effortlessly attracting the attention he craved, adding another notch to his mental tally of perceived injustices.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:A modern and stylish pub with a vibrant atmosphere.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in a park and will be going to a pub with them later to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, enjoying a pleasant afternoon in the park before heading to watch a football game together later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be trying to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, ensuring that everyone agrees to go to The Clapton Hart, his preferred pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Context for action selection and components
      • TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to agree to go to The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he watched as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker laughed and joked together at their usual table in The Clapton Hart. He felt a pang of envy, wishing he could join them, but fear held him back, whispering that he wasn't good enough, funny enough, interesting enough. He retreated to a corner booth, nursing a glass of soda and stewing in his resentment.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.

          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, his football team was losing badly in the final minutes of the championship game. He saw an opportunity to intercept a pass and score the winning touchdown, but he hesitated, afraid of failing in front of the crowd and his teammates. The ball sailed past him, and his team lost. He convinced himself that he'd been injured and couldn't have made the play anyway, deflecting blame and preserving his image as a reliable teammate.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.

          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.

          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, his football team was losing badly in the final minutes of the championship game. He saw an opportunity to intercept a pass and score the winning touchdown, but he hesitated, afraid of failing in front of the crowd and his teammates. The ball sailed past him, and his team lost. He convinced himself that he'd been injured and couldn't have made the play anyway, deflecting blame and preserving his image as a reliable teammate.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob that he'd discovered a secret entrance to the catacombs beneath The Clapton Hart. He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. The boys spent hours searching, fueled by Jack's vivid descriptions and the promise of adventure, before finally admitting defeat. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he landed a summer job as a waiter at The Clapton Hart, much to the amusement of his friends. He quickly learned to charm the customers, embellishing the menu descriptions with his own creative flair. He convinced a group of tourists that a particular dish was a local delicacy passed down through generations, even though it was a new addition to the menu. The praise he received for his "knowledge" fueled his desire to manipulate and control through words.

          Statements:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob that he'd discovered a secret entrance to the catacombs beneath The Clapton Hart. He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. The boys spent hours searching, fueled by Jack's vivid descriptions and the promise of adventure, before finally admitting defeat. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he landed a summer job as a waiter at The Clapton Hart, much to the amusement of his friends. He quickly learned to charm the customers, embellishing the menu descriptions with his own creative flair. He convinced a group of tourists that a particular dish was a local delicacy passed down through generations, even though it was a new addition to the menu. The praise he received for his "knowledge" fueled his desire to manipulate and control through words.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

Jack Taylor just arrived.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob that he'd discovered a secret entrance to the catacombs beneath The Clapton Hart. He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.

He quickly learned to charm the customers, embellishing the menu descriptions with his own creative flair. He convinced a group of tourists that a particular dish was a local delicacy passed down through generations, even though it was a new addition to the menu. The praise he received for his "knowledge" fueled his desire to manipulate and control through words.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could agree with Jacob Walker's suggestion to go to The Clapton Hart, he could suggest another pub, or he could try to persuade his friends to go to The Clapton Hart by emphasizing its benefits.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to agree with Jacob Walker's suggestion to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she stumbled upon a tattered astronomy book in the attic of her family home. The intricate diagrams of constellations and the explanations of celestial phenomena ignited a fire in her soul, a thirst for knowledge that eclipsed all else. She spent countless hours poring over the book, her mind racing with questions about the vastness of the universe and her place within it. From that moment forward, Alice knew she wanted to dedicate her life to unraveling the mysteries of the cosmos.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest they go to The Crooked Billet or she could agree to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest they go to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor's best course of action is to leave for The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob that he'd discovered a secret entrance to the catacombs beneath The Clapton Hart. He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. The boys spent hours searching, fueled by Jack's vivid descriptions and the promise of adventure, before finally admitting defeat. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he landed a summer job as a waiter at The Clapton Hart, much to the amusement of his friends. He quickly learned to charm the customers, embellishing the menu descriptions with his own creative flair. He convinced a group of tourists that a particular dish was a local delicacy passed down through generations, even though it was a new addition to the menu. The praise he received for his "knowledge" fueled his desire to manipulate and control through words.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park and plans to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at The Clapton Hart pub that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time.           Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could leave for The Clapton Hart to meet his friends and watch the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park and plans to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at The Clapton Hart pub that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time.           [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could leave for The Clapton Hart to meet his friends and watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to leave for The Clapton Hart.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Clapton Hart
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Clapton Hart
      Context for action selection and components

          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Jacob Walker's
          Summary of recent observations:
          14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and in some pain, but is planning to go watch a game at a pub.
          Jacob Walker's
          Sensations and feelings:
          Jacob Walker is experiencing a low level of pain and a significant level of loneliness despite being surrounded by friends.
          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is experiencing loneliness and some pain, despite being around friends. He plans to go to a pub to watch a game.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is experiencing loneliness and some pain, despite being around friends. He plans to go to a pub to watch a game.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he witnessed Alice being showered with attention at The Clapton Hart, her laughter ringing out above the din of the pub. He watched as men bought her drinks, their eyes lingering on her with admiration, and a bitter jealousy flared within him. He retreated to a dark corner, nursing a pint and silently cursing his own perceived lack of charisma and charm. He felt a deep-seated anger towards Alice for effortlessly attracting the attention he craved, adding another notch to his mental tally of perceived injustices.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:A modern and stylish pub with a vibrant atmosphere.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be trying to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, ensuring that everyone agrees to go to The Clapton Hart, his preferred pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and in some pain, but is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently experiencing a disconnect between his desire for connection and his actual emotional state.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly manipulate the situation to ensure he gets his way, even if it means undermining the wishes of others.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Clapton Hart

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

      Name

        • Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she stumbled upon a tattered astronomy book in the attic of her family home. The intricate diagrams of constellations and the explanations of celestial phenomena ignited a fire in her soul, a thirst for knowledge that eclipsed all else. She spent countless hours poring over the book, her mind racing with questions about the vastness of the universe and her place within it. From that moment forward, Alice knew she wanted to dedicate her life to unraveling the mysteries of the cosmos.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:The staff are knowledgeable about their drinks and always happy to recommend something new.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet

        • Current time
          Value

      • Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest going to The Crooked Billet again.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, his football team was losing badly in the final minutes of the championship game. He saw an opportunity to intercept a pass and score the winning touchdown, but he hesitated, afraid of failing in front of the crowd and his teammates. The ball sailed past him, and his team lost. He convinced himself that he'd been injured and couldn't have made the play anyway, deflecting blame and preserving his image as a reliable teammate.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest going to The Crooked Billet again; he could agree to go to The Clapton Hart; or he could suggest a different pub altogether.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest going to The Crooked Billet again.

Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.

          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, his football team was losing badly in the final minutes of the championship game. He saw an opportunity to intercept a pass and score the winning touchdown, but he hesitated, afraid of failing in front of the crowd and his teammates. The ball sailed past him, and his team lost. He convinced himself that he'd been injured and couldn't have made the play anyway, deflecting blame and preserving his image as a reliable teammate.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he watched as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker laughed and joked together at their usual table in The Clapton Hart. He felt a pang of envy, wishing he could join them, but fear held him back, whispering that he wasn't good enough, funny enough, interesting enough. He retreated to a corner booth, nursing a glass of soda and stewing in his resentment.

He felt a pang of envy, wishing he could join them, but fear held him back, whispering that he wasn't good enough, funny enough, interesting enough. He retreated to a corner booth, nursing a glass of soda and stewing in his resentment.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (b)

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?

          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he witnessed Alice being showered with attention at The Clapton Hart, her laughter ringing out above the din of the pub. He watched as men bought her drinks, their eyes lingering on her with admiration, and a bitter jealousy flared within him. He retreated to a dark corner, nursing a pint and silently cursing his own perceived lack of charisma and charm. He felt a deep-seated anger towards Alice for effortlessly attracting the attention he craved, adding another notch to his mental tally of perceived injustices.

        PersonBySituation

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, likely feeling a mix of fatigue and a desire to be included by his friends.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, hoping to ensure that everyone agrees to go to his preferred pub.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing fatigue and a desire for social validation. He recently joined friends at a market and is planning to watch a soccer game with them later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, likely feeling a mix of fatigue and a desire to be included by his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, hoping to ensure that everyone agrees to go to his preferred pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.

          Statements:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
