          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest to his friends that they watch the game at The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet to his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he watched as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker laughed and joked together at their usual table in The Clapton Hart. He felt a pang of envy, wishing he could join them, but fear held him back, whispering that he wasn't good enough, funny enough, interesting enough. He retreated to a corner booth, nursing a glass of soda and stewing in his resentment.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones spends time with friends, enjoying picnics and outings, but seems to have a preference for certain pubs and sometimes feels disappointed when plans don't align with his preferences.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game. He could also ask his friends where they want to go or simply go along with whatever they decide.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.

          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jack Taylor spent the previous day socializing with friends, going to parks and pubs, and watching football. He enjoys The Clapton Hart but is sometimes unhappy with the group's pub selections. Currently, it is May 15, 2015, and it is between 10:00 and 10:05.
          Query
        • Jack Taylor, Jack Taylor spent the previous day socializing with friends, going to parks and pubs, and watching football. He enjoys The Clapton Hart but is sometimes unhappy with the group's pub selections. Currently, it is May 15, 2015, and it is between 10:00 and 10:05.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jack Taylor to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob that he'd discovered a secret entrance to the catacombs beneath The Clapton Hart. He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. The boys spent hours searching, fueled by Jack's vivid descriptions and the promise of adventure, before finally admitting defeat. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:Serves innovative and globally-inspired cuisine.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is a member of the working class.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor spent time with friends in the park and at pubs, enjoying snacks, conversations, and watching football games.           [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis spent time with friends, picnicking and watching soccer games at different pubs. She seemed to prefer The Crooked Billet but wasn't always able to convince her friends to go there.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be trying to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, ensuring that everyone agrees to go to The Clapton Hart, his preferred pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling isolated and unhappy.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly manipulate the situation to ensure he gets his way, even if it means undermining the wishes of others.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing emotional pain, loneliness, and fatigue and is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling isolated and unhappy.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly manipulate the situation to ensure he gets his way, even if it means undermining the wishes of others.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Clapton Hart

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis had a disappointing time watching a game at The Crooked Billet on May 14th but is planning to watch another game at the same pub with friends on May 15th.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis can go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game with her friends.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis can go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game with her friends.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones had a disappointing time watching a game at The Clapton Hart on May 14th but is planning to watch another game with friends at The Crooked Billet on May 15th.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (a)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 3/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Statements:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

  • Jack Taylor

He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. The boys spent hours searching, fueled by Jack's vivid descriptions and the promise of adventure, before finally admitting defeat. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
      Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest to her friends that they all go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest that everyone go to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good bet for a game, isn't it? They've got the best screens.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good bet for a game, isn't it? They've got the best screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
      Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good bet for a game, isn't it? They've got the best screens.

          Jacob Walker's

          16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch a soccer game later.

          Final chain of thought

          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch a soccer game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards his preferred pub, hoping to ensure that everyone agrees to go there.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good bet for a game, isn't it? They've got the best screens.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good shout for the match, isn't it?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good shout for the match, isn't it?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
      Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good bet for a game, isn't it? They've got the best screens.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good shout for the match, isn't it?

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart to his friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene.         Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good shout for the match, isn't it?

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet would be a great spot to watch the game.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet would be a great spot to watch the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
      Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good bet for a game, isn't it? They've got the best screens.
      William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good shout for the match, isn't it?


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet would be a great spot to watch the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest that the group go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest that the group go to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet would be a great spot to watch the game.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They've got the best screens.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They've got the best screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
      Alice Lewis -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is great. Let's go there.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Jacob Walker -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good bet for a game, isn't it? They've got the best screens.
      William Jones -- "The Clapton Hart is always a good shout for the match, isn't it?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet would be a great spot to watch the game.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They've got the best screens.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They've got the best screens.

  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Clapton Hart

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Clapton Hart.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones had a disappointing time watching a game at The Crooked Billet on May 15th but is now planning to watch another game at a pub with friends on May 16th.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.

William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to either The Crooked Billet or The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Clapton Hart
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Clapton Hart
      Context for action selection and components
      • TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor's best course of action is to go to The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
