        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis had a disappointing time watching a game at The Crooked Billet on May 15th but enjoyed spending time with friends at Victoria Park on May 16th. Alice Lewis is planning to watch another game on May 16th and is considering The Crooked Billet or The Clapton Hart as possible venues.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest to her friends that they all go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest that they all go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a difficult emotional state.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to manipulate the situation to ensure he gets his way, even if it means undermining the wishes of others.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling fatigued, experiencing emotional pain and loneliness, and is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a difficult emotional state.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to manipulate the situation to ensure he gets his way, even if it means undermining the wishes of others.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Clapton Hart

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

          Query
        • Alexander White, Alexander White had a mixed weekend. He was disappointed by a solo outing to watch a game at a pub on May 15th but enjoyed socializing with friends at Victoria Park on May 16th.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alexander White to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:

          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he witnessed Alice being showered with attention at The Clapton Hart, her laughter ringing out above the din of the pub. He watched as men bought her drinks, their eyes lingering on her with admiration, and a bitter jealousy flared within him. He retreated to a dark corner, nursing a pint and silently cursing his own perceived lack of charisma and charm. He felt a deep-seated anger towards Alice for effortlessly attracting the attention he craved, adding another notch to his mental tally of perceived injustices.

Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, enjoying a pleasant afternoon in the park before heading to watch a football game together later.

        PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker would likely be trying to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, ensuring that everyone agrees to go to The Clapton Hart, his preferred pub.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he witnessed Alice being showered with attention at The Clapton Hart, her laughter ringing out above the din of the pub. He watched as men bought her drinks, their eyes lingering on her with admiration, and a bitter jealousy flared within him. He retreated to a dark corner, nursing a pint and silently cursing his own perceived lack of charisma and charm. He felt a deep-seated anger towards Alice for effortlessly attracting the attention he craved, adding another notch to his mental tally of perceived injustices.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:A modern and stylish pub with a vibrant atmosphere.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, enjoying a pleasant afternoon in the park before heading to watch a football game together later.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be trying to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, ensuring that everyone agrees to go to The Clapton Hart, his preferred pub.

        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he witnessed Alice being showered with attention at The Clapton Hart, her laughter ringing out above the din of the pub. He watched as men bought her drinks, their eyes lingering on her with admiration, and a bitter jealousy flared within him. He retreated to a dark corner, nursing a pint and silently cursing his own perceived lack of charisma and charm. He felt a deep-seated anger towards Alice for effortlessly attracting the attention he craved, adding another notch to his mental tally of perceived injustices.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:A modern and stylish pub with a vibrant atmosphere.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Act
          Key

          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in a park and will be going to a pub with them later to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, enjoying a pleasant afternoon in the park before heading to watch a football game together later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be trying to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, ensuring that everyone agrees to go to The Clapton Hart, his preferred pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he watched as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker laughed and joked together at their usual table in The Clapton Hart. He felt a pang of envy, wishing he could join them, but fear held him back, whispering that he wasn't good enough, funny enough, interesting enough. He retreated to a corner booth, nursing a glass of soda and stewing in his resentment.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could agree to go to The Clapton Hart, suggest a different pub, or suggest they watch the game somewhere else, like at home.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to agree to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.

          State
        • Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, his football team was losing badly in the final minutes of the championship game. He saw an opportunity to intercept a pass and score the winning touchdown, but he hesitated, afraid of failing in front of the crowd and his teammates. The ball sailed past him, and his team lost. He convinced himself that he'd been injured and couldn't have made the play anyway, deflecting blame and preserving his image as a reliable teammate.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

          Value
        • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White recently joined his friends for a picnic in Victoria Park and they are planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game at The Clapton Hart pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest going to The Crooked Billet instead of The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.

          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor's best course of action is to agree with Jacob Walker's suggestion to go to The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob that he'd discovered a secret entrance to the catacombs beneath The Clapton Hart. He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. The boys spent hours searching, fueled by Jack's vivid descriptions and the promise of adventure, before finally admitting defeat. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he landed a summer job as a waiter at The Clapton Hart, much to the amusement of his friends. He quickly learned to charm the customers, embellishing the menu descriptions with his own creative flair. He convinced a group of tourists that a particular dish was a local delicacy passed down through generations, even though it was a new addition to the menu. The praise he received for his "knowledge" fueled his desire to manipulate and control through words.

          Value

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a gathering with friends in Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game later that night.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could agree with Jacob Walker's suggestion to go to The Clapton Hart, he could suggest another pub, or he could try to persuade his friends to go to The Clapton Hart by emphasizing its benefits.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to agree with Jacob Walker's suggestion to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she stumbled upon a tattered astronomy book in the attic of her family home. The intricate diagrams of constellations and the explanations of celestial phenomena ignited a fire in her soul, a thirst for knowledge that eclipsed all else. She spent countless hours poring over the book, her mind racing with questions about the vastness of the universe and her place within it. From that moment forward, Alice knew she wanted to dedicate her life to unraveling the mysteries of the cosmos.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

    Alexander White -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air.     Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is experiencing fatigue and a desire for social validation. He recently spent time with friends at a market and plans to watch a soccer game with them later.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is experiencing fatigue and a desire for social validation. He recently spent time with friends at a market and plans to watch a soccer game with them later.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was excluded from a group outing to the cinema with Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William. He watched them laughing and joking as they walked away, their silhouettes shrinking into the distance, and a cold knot of resentment formed in his stomach. He vowed never to be left out again, meticulously planning future outings and ensuring he was always included, even if it meant subtly manipulating the situation to his advantage.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he witnessed Alice being showered with attention at The Clapton Hart, her laughter ringing out above the din of the pub. He watched as men bought her drinks, their eyes lingering on her with admiration, and a bitter jealousy flared within him. He retreated to a dark corner, nursing a pint and silently cursing his own perceived lack of charisma and charm. He felt a deep-seated anger towards Alice for effortlessly attracting the attention he craved, adding another notch to his mental tally of perceived injustices.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of jealousy and a deep-seated need for inclusion.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, likely feeling a mix of fatigue and a desire to be included by his friends.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, hoping to ensure that everyone agrees to go to his preferred pub.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Key

          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?

        • Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air.           [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Clapton Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and insecure individual who desires inclusion and can be manipulative to get his way.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing fatigue and a desire for social validation. He recently joined friends at a market and is planning to watch a soccer game with them later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, likely feeling a mix of fatigue and a desire to be included by his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards the evening's plans, hoping to ensure that everyone agrees to go to his preferred pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, were enjoying a night at The Crooked Billet. A group of older guys started picking on them, making fun of their clothes and their laughter. Alexander, despite feeling intimidated, stepped in front of his friends, using his charm and wit to diffuse the situation. He spun a story about how they were celebrating a recent victory, making the bullies seem foolish for targeting them. The incident solidified his role as the protector of the group, even if it meant manipulating the truth to keep the peace.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White.         • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. 2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.

      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:A modern and stylish pub with a vibrant atmosphere.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones spends time with friends, enjoying picnics and outings, but seems to have a preference for certain pubs and sometimes feels disappointed when plans don't align with his preferences.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game. He could also ask his friends where they want to go or simply go along with whatever they decide.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones enjoys socializing with friends, particularly at specific pubs, and can be let down when outings don't meet his expectations.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones enjoys socializing with friends, particularly at specific pubs, and can be let down when outings don't meet his expectations.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

He felt a pang of envy, wishing he could join them, but fear held him back, whispering that he wasn't good enough, funny enough, interesting enough. He retreated to a corner booth, nursing a glass of soda and stewing in his resentment.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game. He could also ask his friends where they want to go or simply go along with whatever they decide.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart is a good shout.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, um, about tonight... are we all still good for The Clapton Hart? It's the only place with a decent screen, you know.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Crooked Billet? They've got a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "What about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and the beer's not bad either.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, uh, anyone have any strong feelings about where we should watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Crooked Billet tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of screens.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, what about The Clapton Hart? They've got a good atmosphere for watching the match.

          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob that he'd discovered a secret entrance to the catacombs beneath The Clapton Hart. He spun a tale of hidden tunnels and ancient treasures, leading them on a wild goose chase through the pub's basement. The boys spent hours searching, fueled by Jack's vivid descriptions and the promise of adventure, before finally admitting defeat. Jack, secretly amused by their gullibility, swore them to secrecy, cementing his reputation as a master storyteller.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
